Blue Matters,

John Harris

free

OPENING RECEPTION: Sunday January 13, 3-6pm

           

John Harris

T houghtful portrayals of extensive variety developed from natural images. These Organic abstractions, layers of paint and color, depict the hypnotic and fleeting display of imagery created by water.

Mr. Harris isolates and exaggerates forms, colors and sequences found in nature. His large scale, realist paintings take one to two months to complete, as he meticulously works to recreate various environmental complexities from photographs memory and artistic expression. The process begins with mapping out large shapes of color on canvas then details are added. When the paint dries more paint and glazes are added. The repetition of this careful glazing technique results in the dramatization of translucent layers - a visual effect that is conceptually harmonious with its subject: water.

Harris is most interested in exploring water’s physical properties - reflection, turbidity, rhythm, pattern, that make up its unique viewing experience. He addresses these issues by isolating a moment in time in various bodies of water, painting from a birds eye view. The result is a series of peaceful and hypnotic paintings, in which water is disguised as tree canopies and the skies above.

 

 

Kristina Kuster-Witt

One theme has preoccupied me and been apparent in my work since the mid 1990`s when I lived and studied in Germany and Holland, and that is duality - in every aspect of human life. 

My work evolves around the human figure but I am not painting portraits. Sometimes the figures look androgynous if gender is not important in a particular painting. A large body of my work are oil paintings, often diptychs, that correspond with each other. I often depict inner conflicts, gender assignments or aging. 

My recent series of oil paintings is titled “Blue Matters”. This partly refers to the color blue being important in this series but the second meaning of course refers to actual “matter”. Neutral colored figures interact with various blue colored, undefined material substances.

 In every painting the matter looks different and it is never obvious whether it is for example water or glue, hair or clay, rock or bubble, heavy or light; it could be almost anything. 

The figures interacting with these substances are also accompanied by little black and white figures. These counterparts express 

the duality of the depicted scene, they could be an alter ego or a memory. The figures are frequently upside-down which is a pose I often use as a metaphor for  overcoming ones fears of getting hurt or loosing control, trying to gain a new perspective or simply living more “in the moment”.

In another new series I am reflecting some thoughts regarding the possibilities and dangers of DNA research. Two figures are connected by a double Helix or “twisted ladder”, possibly corresponding about which gender or color (maybe green?) their child should have.  

Aside from being a painter I also work as a printmaker. Over the past couple of years I started transforming elements of my paintings into prints using a transfer technique called paper lithography.

Each print is unique since the printing plate is only a Xerox paper. I also add up to three layers of monoprints. This fascinating process  enables me to work more experimental and improvisational and the boundaries between the figure and abstraction dissolve more and more.

Lately I also started to paint on the prints. This mixed media process creates a new tension caused by  the layering or partially burying of the images. The image does not transform back into the painting it came from though but is "recycled" into a new life.

 I like for my imagery to have its own clarity and subtlety but at the same time address a world of uncertainty, complexity and obscurity.

parking behind Kehler Liddell
